children.subject: Not sure if this has been commented on yet but I'm curious, will the same industry reps be returning next semester? Or is it too early to say?
or is the class simply capped at 85 ? Need to know soon so I can jump off the waitlist and enroll in something else haha 😢
Remember, this class is combined grad & undergrad class. It's listed as CS 160/260A. The remainder of the seats will go to the grad side of the class.

what is the capacity of the class? I see that there are 120 seats, but only 85 are enrolled. Does that mean 35 students are going to get off the waitlist some time? And if so, will seniors and CS majors be prioritized?

This information has also been posted on class piazza page but I'm adding it here as well. This was written by Prof for class.

CS160 Enrollment FAQ

Many students are currently contacting me to ask about ways to enroll in CS160 for Spring 2020. Unfortunately this course is strongly oversubscribed. As a project-centered design course, where you complete open-ended projects of your own choice in teams, CS160 cannot scale as well as other CS courses.

* The total enrollment limit of CS160 and CS260A, which are room-shared, is 120 students (90 undergraduates in 160, 30 graduates in 260A). We will not be able to increase enrollment to accommodate the level of interest in this course beyond that point.

* We are using the registrar's algorithm for assigning priority in enrollment and waitlist position and cannot make individual exceptions.

* Only undergraduate students can enroll in CS160. Only graduate students can enroll in CS260A.

Given the large wait list, there is no way to process enrollment requests without causing a lot of disappointment. Many outstanding students who show strong interest in the subject of user interface design will not be able to enroll.

To help you make alternative plans, here are some strategies to either enroll in CS160 in the future, or learn similar material at Berkeley and elsewhere:

* If you have additional semesters at Cal, we encourage you to try again in the future - CS160 is taught every fall and spring, and increasingly, in summer semesters as well. Summer offerings during the past few years have had shorter waitlists than fall or spring offerings.

* DES INV 25, User Experience Design, is a good alternate course. It teaches principles of human-centered design without the implementation focus of CS160. It may be especially appropriate for non-CS/EECS majors. This course will likely be offered next in fall 2020.
http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/des_inv/

* Graduate students can also take INFO 213.This course will likely be offered next in fall 2020.
https://www.ischool.berkeley.edu/courses/info/213

* To learn about human-centered design in general (without a specific focus on user interfaces), you can enroll in DES INV 15, Design Methodology, which is offered in spring 2020: https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2020-spring-desinv-15-001-lec-001

* If you are unable to enroll in a course at Berkeley, but would like to learn CS160 topics on your own time outside of class, the Interaction Design Specialization from UC San Diego on Coursera is worthwhile: https://www.coursera.org/specializations/interaction-design

If you are graduating, we are sorry that we could not accommodate you, but we wish you the best for your future.

We hope you will all have a successful semester.

history.content:
Unfortunately at this point CS 160 is enrolled to capacity and the wait list is also full. As in past semesters, there are no plans to expand the class.  Many of the wait listed students will not be able to enroll into the class. 

In order to signal realistic expectations, we will NOT expand the wait list past 100 spaces. We realize how frustrating this is for many students. Unfortunately given the format of the class and the space constraints, there is just no way to expand the class at this time.
history.subject: SP20: CS 160/260A will NOT expand, wait list for CS 160 is CLOSED
